thesis.description: I propose to divide my subject, the question of Asiatic immigration into British Columbia, into three chief divisions:- 1. Assimilation or non-assimilation and a brief sketch of thecharacters and characteristics of Asiatics; 2. The economic aspect of the situation; 3. The histories of the immigration movements of the three nationalities to be considered, namely the Chinese, the Japanese and the Hindu, and of the legislation against them. In conclusion I will consider the subject in its national, imperial and international aspects. [...]
thesis.creator: Ellison, Myra K.
thesis.contributor: Leacock, S. & Walter, H. & Fryer, C. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: Economics & Political Science.
thesis.title: The Asiatic immigration question in British Columbia.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Sigia Oceanica, the Species worked upon, is found on the sea-shore probably forming the connecting link between the isopods of the sea and the terrestrial forms. 1. Did Sigia voluntarily enter the sea? 2. Can Sigia be carried from one habitable zone to another by the sea? i.e., across an uninhabitable stretch of land. 3. Has Sigia sprung directly from sea stock, or have its ancestors passed through a fresh water period before finally becoming land creatures? By determining the blood concentration and constituents this information could be found. Experiments were then tried to find in what dilution of sea-water the animals could stand immersion without injury. [...]
thesis.creator: Emmons, William F.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Further immersion experiments and observations on some of the terrestrial Crustaceae.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A general view of the advancing status of women in the last century - political and legal rights - marriage - industrial status, etc. Examples of France, England, United States, New Zealand, etc. The struggle for democracy has for the last 25 years been closely connected with what is popularly known as the movement for "Women's Rights" comprising of course the vote, the right to hold office, higher education, the entrance to the professions, etc. [...]

thesis.description: During the summer of 1912, Dr J.A. Bancroft, Associate Professor of Geology at McGill University, was instructed by the Quebec Department of Mines to make a geological reconnaissance of the District North of Transcontinental Railway in North Western Quebec. Having been fortunate enough to accompany Dr Bancroft as assistant, I submit, in this paper, the results of a geological examination of the Country surrounding Gull & Olga Lakes, of which I made an independent investigation. thesis.description: The purpose of this essay is to present the historical background of the international controversy which has arisen out of the arrangement made for the payment of tolls in the recent legislation of the United States Congress known as the Panama Canal Act. Section 5 of that Bill contains the words "No tolls shall be levied upon vessels engaged in the coastwise trade of the United States." Great Britain has formally declared that she considers this clause a violation of the Hay-Pauncefote Treaty. [...]

thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: The history of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty.

thesis.description: Before entering upon the discussion of the various instincts, the purposes they serve, and the extent of their distribution among the many species of animals and their effects upon the mental and social life of man, it would be well to determine at the outset just what is meant by an instinct; what is meant by instinctive action. Early writers on this subject defined instinct in a number of ways. There was great diversity of opinion among even the most eminent psychologists. [...]

thesis.contributor: Tait, W. & Dale, J. & Harkness, J. (Supervisors)

thesis.title: MacDougall's theory of the instincts.

thesis.description: Asphalt is a commodity of continually increasing importance. Although its chief use is still as a binder in the construction of asphalt pavements, it is not limited to this, but is now utilized in the manufacture of paints, varnishes, roofing material, insulating material etc. Much has been written about the physical and chemical properties of asphalt as a whole, such as change in structure upon heating, exposure to light and air, the action of solvents and acids, yet amongst this mass of literature one finds very little information on their ultimate chemical constitution. [...]
thesis.creator: Seyer, William F.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: A chemical investigation of the asphalt in the tar sands of northern Alberta.

thesis.description: SCOPE OF THE THESIS. In dealing with a subject of such importance and magnitude, it is difficult out of the great mass of data and phenomena to select the materials that will most effectively emphasize the special phases of the subject submitted, without apparently doing injustice to departments of the larger subject that are of very great interest. In order to make clear the value of the sociological movement among the people whose history is largely given in the Old Testament it will be necessary to consider the conditions by which they were surrounded, the characteristics and customs of the people with which they came in contact, the changes in their own history that marked their development from their primitive nomadic condition to a well organized nation, and to examine the laws and principles by which that development took place. [...]

thesis.subject: Semitic Studies.
thesis.title: Biblical sociology.

thesis.description: Object of the Experiment. The immediate object of these experiments was to determine the electomot1ve force induced in magnetic conductors and insulators when rotated in a magnetic field. Two main theories of the results to be expected are possible, according as one supposes the part of the magnetic field due to the substance itself to be carried round with the substance or to remain at rest. It is evident that the settlement of the claims of these two theories should afford a possible solution or the ever-recurr1ng problem as to whether the lines of force or a rotating symmetrica1 magnet are stationary or rotate with the magnet. All previous attempts to settle this question have proved fruitless as the calculated effect is the same on either view. [...]
thesis.creator: Paterson-Smyth, Marjorie E.
thesis.contributor: Barnes, H. & Harkness, J. & Wilson, H. (Supervisors)
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: On the effect of rotating magnetic matter ina magnetic field.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Flotation on the other hand, developed almost entirely without the previsionery aid afforded by science, rests on principles failing within that branch of science of physical chemistry called colloidal chemistry, which itself affords unlimited possibilities for research. In fact the clearing up of the theoretical side of flotation will lie directly in the path of the work done to throw more light on the subject of colloidal chemistry. [...]
